He adopts Savigny's theory that there were, from the first, two different modes os proceeding against insolvent debtors: the one-manus iniectio or personal execution-applying only where the judgment or confession on which execution issued was on a money loan, real (mutuum) or fictitious (nexum) or on certain other obligations assimilated by statute to mutuum, Gaius iv. ης the other, or execution against the property, being resorted to in all other cases. Α commoner view is that, until about roo lac, manus iniectio (though its severities were mitigated by the lex Poetelia, Livy viii. 28) was the only remedy open to a creditor ir his debtor refused or was unable to satisfy a judgment debt ; about which time a new form os execution against the property, or real execution, was introduced by the Edict, ol which a leading feature was sale of the bankrupt's universitas iuris by auction to the bidder who offered the creditors the highest percentage on their claims, this praetorian form os bankruptcy execution being called bonorum emptio or venditio, and being described by Gaius (iii. 77-81) as one os the kinds oi universal succession.

Though it is difficolt to come to any definite conclusion on so obscure a topic, the latter view seems best supported by the facts, apart from its inherent probability on grounds os historical jurisprudence. Savigny has to prove two positions: first, that personal execution was confined to the classes os debts specified3 and second, that a system ol real execu- tion was in vogue at Rome srom the earliest times.

ln support os the former he calls attention to what seems an un· deniable lact, viz. that the Romans always drew a broad distinction between debts incurred by money loans and all other debts, and cites various authors (e. g.
